_exec_summary.SummaryText:
MG INDUSTRIES

Jessup, MD Cylinder Gas Production Plant

RMP Executive Summary

Introduction - M G Industries Quality Management and EHS Program  
 
The Quality management system refers to the prevention of potential losses to M G Industries through an effectively designed, administered and implemented Environmental, Health, Safety and Regulatory Compliance Program.

Incorporating an effective loss prevention program requires developing and integrating programs that will assist in reducing losses from accidents. M G Industries has developed Safety, Health and Environmental guidelines that have been incorporated in a comprehensive program defined as Quality Operating Procedures. These procedures are the minimal standards for M G Industries operations, including the Jessup, MD cylinder gas production facility.

The objective of the program is to achieve an acceptable level of performance in the prevention of the losses to the organization which include but are not limited to accidents, injuries, illnesses, product liabilities and regulatory non-conformities. To be effective, this management system must be totally integrated in which all levels of employees are involved and held accountable.

The ultimate authority for instituting an effective EHS Program rests with the senior management of each operating group. Through their words and more importantly through their actions, senior management sets the tone for loss prevention throughout M G Industries. While senior management set the tone, middle management must create the uniform support and nurture the desired culture to influence the EHS Program. This strong management commitment culminates with the day to day responsibilities of implementing and managing the Quality Operating Procedures by 'line management' (supervisors and lead personnel). Local management is accountable for the effective management of this program through their organization's performance as related to loss prevention and regulator

y compliance.

In a healthy Quality Management culture, each member of the company participates fully in the program. Quality Management is no longer an activity that someone else is in charge of. Each manager, supervisor, driver and line worker is personally responsible for insuring 'safe working conditions, safe product for all customers and a safe environment for the citizens of the communities in which M G Industries operates'.
           
Simplified Process Description

MG Industries' cylinder gas plant in Jessup, MD fills industrial gases and acetylene gas into compressed gas cylinders. As part of the operation, large quantities of chemicals are stored in bulk storage tanks and acetylene is generated for transfilling into cylinders. Of all the chemicals inventoried in the Jessup plant, only the following chemicals come under Risk Management Plan (RMP) regulations: propane and acetylene.

All the processes in this facility come under Program 3 of the RMP regulations






General Accidental Release Prevention Program  - Quality Management and EHS Program 

Summary 

The objective of the M G Industries EHS Program is to achieve an acceptable level of performance in the prevention of the losses to the organization. The paramount importance of our Quality Management Program is assuring safe working conditions of our employees, safe product for customers and a safe environment for the citizens of the communities in which we operate. The program is integrated with a series of Standard Operating Procedures that are the cornerstone of M G Industries Quality Program. These procedures form our Quality Operating Procedures Manual. This manual is maintained by local management and is available for review by any employee upon request during normal business hours. In addition, com

pliance with local and federal regulations such as DOT, FDA and EPA are required.

Authority and Responsibility for Program Implementation

The Facility Manager has the overall site authority for implementation of the EHS Program. He or she is responsible for the day to day management of the SOP's as they directly relate to all operational activities.

The Site Safety Coordinator is responsible for conducting periodic inspections, serving as the facility spokesperson on loss prevention issues and participation on the safety committee.

System for Identifying, Evaluating and Preventing Safety and Health Hazards

The system for identifying, evaluating and preventing occupational safety and health hazards has been defined throughout the Quality Operating Procedures Manual and this includes, but not limited to:

- Review of applicable standards to the industry
- Review and availability of Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDSs)
- Ensure the proper labeling of potentially hazardous materials
- Safety work permitting systems
- Investigation of accidents and incidents
- Periodic and scheduled inspection of the general work areas.




Employee Communications and Training

Employee communications and training are also defined throughout the Quality Operating Procedures Manual and these include but not limited to:

- Site specific Safety Bulletin Board for posting all environmental, health and safety related information such as the EHS Policy.
- Site specific safety committee made up of representative functional positions within the operation
- Monthly safety meetings held on various environmental, health and safety topics
- Safety orientation of all new hires and personnel transferred into new positions
- Regulatory compliance training as it may apply to specific operations and/or exposures such as hearing conservation, HAZCOM (Hazard Communications), respiratory protection and fire extinguishers.
- Corporate teleconferencing training
- Emergency

Response and Emergency Action Plan 

Process Safety Features

This facility is manned 14 hours/weekday with routine in-house inspections by plant employees and protected by an alarm system at all other times. The plant has an evacuation plan based on audible signals. The propane storage tanks are protected with excess flow shut off valves and the acetylene plant has a deluge water system. All of the RMP processes come under Process Safety Management (PSM) rules and have been reviewed and audited in the past year.         
      
Five Year Accident History

There were no accidental releases of any of the RMP regulated chemicals from the MG Industries cylinder gas plant in Jessup, MD during the past five years.

Emergency Response Program

The local fire department performs periodic visits to the facility and is a part of the facility emergency action plan. The fire department plays a critical role in this plan. MG Industries relies on the fire department to assist in the control and mitigation of an incident in this site, whereas MG Industries provides the technical expertise with respect to the equipment and the product. A comprehensive EHS Program exists at the facility that is managed both locally and at the MG Industries corporate level.
    
Planned Changes to Improve Safety

MG Industries is committed to continually improving our safety performance for all the operating units of the business. This is reflected in our 'Environmental, Health and Safety  Policy' which states ' ..... All accidents, injuries and occupational illnesses are preventable. Practicing safety is a condition of employment for all employees. This means working safely, reporting unsafe acts and conditions, and actively participating in improving the company's environmental, health, and safety process.'
